title.narrative: CAPACITY TO ENSURE Open Defecation Free (ODF) STATUS,ACCESS TOSAFE DRINKING WATER AND HYGIENE PRACTICES

description.narrative: Deprived communities, schools and health facilities have increased capacity to ensure open-defecation-free status, access to and use of a safely managed drinking water supply, and individual and collective adoption of appropriate hygiene practices, which contributes to Sanitation, Water. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Developing And Leveraging Resources And Partnerships, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: WATER, SANITATION & HYGIENE- Improved and equitable use of safe drinking water, sanitation, and healthy environments and improved hygiene practices in deprived provinces and vulnerable areas.

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: Deprived communities, schools and health facilities have increased capacity to ensure open-defecation-free status, access to and use of a safely managed drinking water supply, and individual and collective adoption of appropriate hygiene practices

description.narrative: By the end of June 35,886 people from 10 communities across six provinces gained access to an improved drinking water source and 364 communities achieved open defecation free verification, covering 152,880 people in 13 districts of nine provinces. | Status:On-track | As-of Date:30/06/2020

title.narrative: Number of schools (including CBEs/ALCs) provided with separate sanitation facilities for boys and girls and hand washing facilities
Number of health centres with staff triggered for hygiene behavioural change, especially washing hands with water and soap
Number of people accessing a sustainable drinking water service in the reporting year only
Number of communities certified free of open defecation in the reporting year only as a result of UNICEF direct support
